dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: You know, I think a lot of people assume that migration to Kazakhstan is mostly from nearby Slavic countries, but that's not the case.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: You know, I think a lot of people assume that migration to Kazakhstan is mostly from nearby Slavic countries, but that's not the case.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Oh, absolutely—like this year alone, almost half of the ethnic Kazakhs returning actually came from China, which is uh, 48.1 percent.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Oh, absolutely-like this year alone, almost half of the ethnic Kazakhs returning actually came from China, which is uh, forty eight point one percent.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: 48.1 percent of kandas who arrived in Kazakhstan since the beginning of the year came from China, 39.5 percent from Uzbekistan, 5.8 percent from Turkmenistan, 2.5 percent from Mongolia, 1.9 percent from Russia, and 2.2 percent from other countries.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Right, and over 1.1 million have returned since 1991—that's a huge number for the country's demographics.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Right, and over one point one million have returned since nineteen ninety one-that's a huge number for the country's demographics.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: In total, since 1991, more than 1,151,000 ethnic Kazakhs have returned to the republic, the statement says.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, and it's interesting that most of them are of working age, like 60 percent or so.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, and it's interesting that most of them are of working age, like sixty percent or so.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: As of April 1, 2025, 60.7 percent of ethnic migrants are of working age, 31.1 percent are minors, and 8.2 percent are retirees.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Mhm, and among those, more than half only have a general secondary education, which is around 52.9 percent.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Mhm, and among those, more than half only have a general secondary education, which is around fifty two point nine percent.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Among the working-age kandas, 17.9 percent have higher education, 27.8 percent have secondary vocational education, 52.9 percent have general secondary education, and 1.4 percent have no education.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: But still, a decent chunk have higher education too—almost 18 percent, which is pretty significant.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: But still, a decent chunk have higher education too-almost eighteen percent, which is pretty significant.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Among the working-age kandas, 17.9 percent have higher education, 27.8 percent have secondary vocational education, 52.9 percent have general secondary education, and 1.4 percent have no education.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: And they're being directed to specific regions that need workers, like Akmola and Abai.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And they're being directed to specific regions that need workers, like Akmola and Abai.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: However, specific labor-deficient regions have been designated for kandas resettlement: Akmola, Abai, Kostanay, Pavlodar, Atyrau, West Kazakhstan, East Kazakhstan, and North Kazakhstan regions.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, the government's offering some solid support too—like a one-time relocation subsidy of 275,000 tenge per person.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, the government's offering some solid support too-like a one-time relocation subsidy of two hundred seventy five thousand tenge per person.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Kandas settling in the above-mentioned regions are provided with government support measures, including a one-time relocation subsidy of 70 MCI (275,200 tenge) for the head and each family member; and monthly subsidies for rent and utilities for one year ranging from 15 to 30 MCI (59,000 to 118,000 tenge).

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: That's not bad at all. Plus they get help with rent and utilities for a whole year, up to like 118,000 tenge monthly in some cases.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: That's not bad at all. Plus they get help with rent and utilities for a whole year, up to like one hundred eighteen thousand tenge monthly in some cases.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Kandas settling in the above-mentioned regions are provided with government support measures, including a one-time relocation subsidy of 70 MCI (275,200 tenge) for the head and each family member; and monthly subsidies for rent and utilities for one year ranging from 15 to 30 MCI (59,000 to 118,000 tenge).

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: It makes sense though—they want to encourage settlement in those labor-deficient areas.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: It makes sense though-they want to encourage settlement in those labor-deficient areas.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Definitely. And the quota for this year is just over 2,300 people for those regions.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Definitely. And the quota for this year is just over two thousand, three hundred people for those regions.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The kandas admission quota for 2025 in these resettlement regions is 2,309 people.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: It's fascinating how this has been building since the nineties—over a million people returning to their historical homeland.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: It's fascinating how this has been building since the nineties-over a million people returning to their historical homeland.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Really puts the cultural and economic landscape into perspective, doesn't it?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Really puts the cultural and economic landscape into perspective, doesn't it?

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: For sure. And with such varied origins—Uzbekistan, Mongolia, even Russia…
dialogue_turns.tts_text: For sure. And with such varied origins-Uzbekistan, Mongolia, even Russia...
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: 48.1 percent of kandas who arrived in Kazakhstan since the beginning of the year came from China, 39.5 percent from Uzbekistan, 5.8 percent from Turkmenistan, 2.5 percent from Mongolia, 1.9 percent from Russia, and 2.2 percent from other countries.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: It's a quiet but major demographic shift happening right there.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: It's a quiet but major demographic shift happening right there.
